Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Supplemental Fluid Administration on Postoperative Wound Infections in Elective Colon Resections

Background: Adequate wound perfusion and oxygenation are essential to prevent postoperative wound infections. This study investigates whether supplemental fluid administration during and after elective colon resections decreases the incidence of postoperative wound infections.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial included patients undergoing open colon resection, randomly assigned to small volume (8 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=124) or large volume (16-18 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=129) fluid management. The primary outcome was the incidence of surgical wound infections, defined by purulent exudate with culture-positive pathogenic bacteria or CDC criteria, assessed by a blinded observer within 15 days post-surgery. Wound healing was evaluated using the ASEPSIS scoring system. Randomisation was conducted using [randomisation method], with allocation concealment ensured by [method]. Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Results: In the small fluid group, 14 patients developed surgical wound infections, compared to 11 in the large fluid group (P=0.46). ASEPSIS scores were similar between groups: 7±16 (small volume) vs. 8±14 (large volume), P=0.70. No significant adverse events were reported in either group. The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Interpretation: The study suggests that supplemental hydration within the tested range does not significantly affect the rate of wound infections or wound healing scores in patients undergoing elective colon resection.
